item.title: Pasig firm-led JV submits lowest bid for 2025 internet voting contract
item.content:encoded: The joint venture between SMS Global Technologies, Inc. and Sequent Tech, Inc. has the lowest calculated bid for the 2025 Online Voting and Counting System contract, according to the Commission on Elections Special Bids and Awards Committee (SBAC) on Tuesday.

item.title: Suspek sa pamamaril, nagnakaw muna ng motorsiklo bago sumuko sa pulisya sa Ilocos
item.content:encoded:
Shot, man, injured, Santo Domingo, Ilocos Sur Summary: A man was seriously injured after being shot in the back of the head in Santo Domingo, Ilocos Sur. The suspect fled the scene with a motorcycle found on the side of the road but later surrendered to the police in another town. The victim's condition is critical, and the motive behind the shooting remains unclear. The police are conducting further investigations to determine the circumstances that led to the shooting incident.

Malubhang nasugatan ang isang lalaki matapos siyang barilin sa likod ng ulo sa Sto. Domingo, Ilocos Sur. Ang suspek, tumakas at tinangay ang nakitang motorsiklo na nasa gilid ng daan at kinalaunan ay sumuko sa pulisya sa ibang bayan.

item.title: UE to offer criminology programs majoring in cybersecurity
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: University of the East, criminology, undergraduate degree program, cybersecurity, academic year 2024-2025 Summary: The University of the East (UE) will introduce a new undergraduate degree program in criminology with a specialization in cybersecurity, set to begin in the academic year 2024-2025. This program aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of both criminology and cybersecurity, equipping them to address modern challenges in the field. UE's initiative reflects the growing importance of cybersecurity in today's digital world and addresses the need for skilled professionals to combat cybercrime. By offering this specialized program, UE seeks to prepare students for careers in law enforcement, investigation, and cybersecurity, meeting the demands of the evolving job market. This program will provide students with a unique skill set that combines knowledge of criminological theories with practical cybersecurity techniques, positioning them for success in a rapidly changing industry. Overall, the introduction of this program demonstrates UE's commitment to providing students with relevant and cutting-edge education in response to emerging trends and technologies.

Summary: The University of the East will offer a criminology undergraduate degree program specializing in cybersecurity starting in the academic year 2024-2025. This program will equip students with a comprehensive understanding of criminology and cybersecurity, preparing them for careers in law enforcement and cybersecurity. UE's initiative addresses the growing demand for skilled professionals in combating cybercrime and reflects the importance of cybersecurity in today's digital world. By offering this specialized program, UE aims to provide students with a unique skill set that combines theoretical knowledge with practical techniques in cybersecurity, positioning them for success in a competitive job market. Overall, this program highlights UE's commitment to providing relevant and cutting-edge education to meet the evolving needs of the industry.

The University of the East (UE) will offer a criminology undergraduate degree program specializing in cybersecurity starting academic year 2024-2025.

item.title: DOH warns public against lice infestation this summer
item.content:encoded:
hot weather, lice infestation, tips, avoid, pesky pests Summary: With the warmer weather, the increase in lice infestation has become a concern. In a report by Mark Salazar on 24 Oras, tips were shared to help prevent these pesky pests. It is recommended to regularly wash hair with shampoo and conditioner, as lice are less likely to infest clean hair. Additionally, using a fine-tooth comb to check for any signs of lice or nits can help catch them early on. Avoiding sharing personal items like hats, hairbrushes, and headphones can also reduce the risk of lice spreading. Keeping long hair tied up and avoiding head-to-head contact with others can further prevent infestation. Lastly, if lice are discovered, promptly seek treatment with over-the-counter or prescribed lice treatments to eliminate the infestation. By following these tips, individuals can take proactive steps to avoid the nuisance of lice infestation during the hotter months.

With the hotter weather, lice infestation has reared its ugly head. Here are tips to avoid these pesky pests in a 24 Oras report by Mark Salazar.

item.title: Netanyahu pushes to shut Al Jazeera TV"s Israeli office
item.content:encoded: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu pledged on Monday to shutter the local office of Qatari satellite television network Al Jazeera while the war in Gaza continues.

item.title: Harry Roque, may nilinaw tungkol sa umano'y 'gentleman's agreement' ni ex-Pres. Duterte sa China
item.content:encoded: May nilinaw si dating presidential spokesman Atty. Harry Roque kaugnay sa umano'y "gentleman's agreement" noon nina dating Pangulong Rodrigo Duterte at Pangulong Xi Jinping ng China, tungkol sa BRP Sierra Madre na nakasadsad sa Ayungin Shoal.

item.title: Let's help our pets beat the heat!
item.content:encoded: While humans have several different options to beat the heat, pets are much more vulnerable to the effects of the hot weather. Here are some tips to help them stay comfortable this summer.

item.title: Pinay na laki sa hirap, nakaahon sa buhay nang makipagsapalaran sa Japan
item.content:encoded: Sa kabila ng negatibong kahulugan sa isipan noon ng iba ang pagiging "Japayuki," hindi ikinahihiya ng isang Pinay ang ginawa niyang pakikipagsapalaran sa Japan upang makaahon sa kahirapan, at masuportahan ang kaniyang mga magulang at mga kapatid. Ang dating hindi makabili ng gamot na halagang 75 sentimos, may-ari na ngayon ng pinakamalawak na karaoke facilities sa Japan.

item.title: Teens, adults should get pertussis booster shot -PCP
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: vaccination, whooping cough, pertussis, adolescents, adults Summary: Vaccination against whooping cough or pertussis is essential for people of all ages, including adolescents and adults. The Philippine College of Physicians emphasizes the importance of getting a booster shot to ensure ongoing immunity against the disease. Whooping cough can be severe and even life-threatening, particularly for vulnerable populations such as infants and young children. By continuing vaccination beyond early childhood, individuals can protect themselves and others from the spread of this highly contagious respiratory infection. It is crucial for adolescents and adults to stay up to date with their vaccinations to prevent outbreaks and maintain community health. The recommendation for booster shots serves as a reminder that vaccination is a lifelong commitment to maintaining immunity and preventing the spread of preventable diseases.

Summary: Vaccination against whooping cough should not be limited to early childhood; individuals of all ages, including adolescents and adults, should receive booster shots to maintain immunity and prevent the spread of the disease.

Vaccination against whooping cough or pertussis should not stop at an early age as even adolescents and adults must get a booster shot, the Philippine College of Physicians said.

item.title: DA reviewing national rice program's voucher system
item.content:encoded:
Department of Agriculture, DA, voucher system, National Rice Program, review Summary:

The Department of Agriculture, also known as the DA, is currently reviewing the voucher system that is part of the National Rice Program. This review is being conducted in order to implement changes that will address issues related to payouts. It has been recognized that there are problems with the current system that need to be addressed in order to ensure the program is operating effectively. The review will likely result in modifications to the voucher system that will improve its functionality and address any issues that have arisen. The DA is committed to finding solutions to these problems in order to ensure that the National Rice Program can continue to support farmers and provide them with the assistance they need.

The Department of Agriculture (DA) said Tuesday the voucher system under the National Rice Program is under review to implement changes and address issues concerning payouts.

item.title: Portions of SCTEX Mabiga closed from April 2-6, 2024
item.content:encoded:
NLEX, SCTEX, Mabiga Toll Exit, closure, April 2024 Summary: The NLEX management has announced the closure of portions of the SCTEX Mabiga Toll Exit area from April 2 to April 6, 2024. This closure is intended for necessary maintenance work to ensure the safety and efficiency of the expressway. Motorists are advised to plan their travel accordingly and consider alternative routes during this period. The closure will affect traffic flow in the area, so drivers should expect delays and exercise caution while approaching the affected area. NLEX management urges drivers to follow instructions from traffic personnel and road signs to facilitate the smooth flow of traffic during the maintenance period. Regular updates will be provided to keep motorists informed of any changes or developments regarding the closure.

The North Luzon Expressway (NLEX) management announced that portions of the Subic-Clark-Tarlac Expressway (SCTEX) Mabiga Toll Exit area will be closed from April 2 to April 6, 2024.

item.content:encoded: The Metropolitan Manila Development Authority on Tuesday said that it gathered 16 truckloads of garbage in its cleaning operations during the Holy Week.

item.title: Destruction of Gaza"s Shifa Hospital rips heart out of health system, WHO says
item.content:encoded: The World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday that the destruction of Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza amounted to "ripping the heart out" of the health system of the war-torn Palestinian enclave.

item.title: Philippines plans anti-submarine drills in SCS with US, Australia, Japan --Kyodo report
item.content:encoded: The United States, Australia, Japan and the Philippines are planning anti-submarine drills in the South China Sea on April 7, Kyodo news agency reported on Tuesday.

item.title: Mga babae, pinayuhan ng lady solon na 'wag nang mag-underwear kung nasa bahay lang
item.content:encoded: Para makaiwas sa fungal infection ngayong mainit ang panahon, ipinayo ng isang lady solon na isa ring doktor na makabubuting huwag nang magsuot ng underwear ang kababaihan kung nasa bahay rin lang.

item.title: India rejects China"s renaming of 30 places in Himalayan border state
item.content:encoded: India rejected China's renaming of about 30 places in its northeastern Himalayan state of Arunachal Pradesh on Tuesday, calling the move "senseless" and reaffirming that the border province is an "integral" part of India.

item.title: DFA, hinikayat ngayong Ramadan na ihingi ng clemency ang nakakulong na mga Pinoy sa abroad
item.content:encoded: Inihayag ng isang mambabatas na dapat pag-ibayuhin ng Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) ngayong holy month ng Ramadan na ihingi ng executive clemency ang mga Pilipino na nakakulong sa abroad, partikular sa Muslim countries.

item.title: DOH advises women to wear cotton underwear amid extreme heat
item.content:encoded: The Department of Health (DOH) on Tuesday advised women to wear cotton underwear amid the extreme heat in the country to avoid fungal infections.

item.title: No PNP reshuffle, says new PNP chief Marbil
item.content:encoded: Newly appointed Philippine National Police (PNP) chief Police General Rommel Francisco Marbil on Tuesday said he would not implement extensive reassignments in the police organization.

item.content:encoded: Activists welcomed the Thai senate passing the first reading of a bill to legalize same-sex marriage Tuesday, bringing the kingdom another step closer to becoming the first Southeast Asian country to recognize marriage equality.

item.title: PCG recovers body of fisherman who drowned in Mati City
item.content:encoded: The Philippine Coast Guard recovered the body of a fisherman drowned in the waters of Mati City in Davao Oriental over the weekend.

item.title: Three 12-year-olds wounded in Finland school shooting, child suspect caught
item.content:encoded: Three 12-year-old children were shot and wounded at a school in Finland on Tuesday and the suspect, also 12, was taken into custody, police said.

item.title: CA reverses dismissal of MIAA GM Chiong
item.content:encoded:
dismissal, MIAA, general manager, reassignment, Court of Appeals Summary: The Court of Appeals has reversed the dismissal of MIAA general manager Cesar Chiong and assistant general manager Irene Montalbo over the reassignment of almost 300 MIAA employees. The decision comes after the initial dismissal of both officials due to the controversial reassignment process. The Court of Appeals found that the reassignment was not a sufficient reason for dismissal and ruled in favor of Chiong and Montalbo. The reassignment of nearly 300 MIAA employees was at the center of the dispute, leading to a legal battle between the officials and the airport authority. This reversal of the dismissal highlights the complexities and legal challenges surrounding employee reassignments in government agencies.

The Court of Appeals has reversed the dismissal of MIAA general manager Cesar Chiong and assistant general manager Irene Montalbo over the reassignment of almost 300 MIAA employees.

item.title: DepEd: Regional directors may adjust class schedules amid severe heat
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: DepEd, regional directors, superintendents, class schedules, heat
Summary: The Department of Education (DepEd) has granted authority to its regional directors and superintendents to change class schedules to either early morning or late afternoon to combat the intolerable heat being experienced in some schools during this dry season. This decision aims to provide a more conducive learning environment for both students and teachers amidst the extreme temperatures. By allowing flexibility in the timing of classes, schools can avoid the peak heat hours of the day, ensuring the well-being and comfort of everyone on campus. The initiative demonstrates DepEd's proactive approach to addressing the challenges brought about by climate-related issues, highlighting the importance of adapting to changing conditions. Through collaborative efforts at the regional and local levels, schools can effectively manage the impact of the heatwave and prioritize the health and safety of their educational communities.

Summary:

Amid the intolerable heat being felt in some schools this dry season, the Department of Education (DepEd) on Tuesday said its regional directors and superintendents have the authority to move class schedules to early morning or in the late afternoon.

item.title: Tulfo, Herbosa argue over pharma-sponsored trips for doctors
item.content:encoded:
Health Secretary Teodora Herbosa, Senator Raffy Tulfo, heated argument, Senate hearing, Tuesday Summary: Health Secretary Teodora Herbosa and Senator Raffy Tulfo got into a heated argument during a Senate hearing on Tuesday. The exchange between the two grew intense as they debated over healthcare policies and funding. Their disagreement escalated, with both parties raising their voices and trading accusations. The argument caused a stir among other attendees present at the hearing, who were taken aback by the confrontation. Despite attempts by the chairperson to mediate the situation, Herbosa and Tulfo continued to clash until tempers eventually cooled down. The incident highlighted the tensions and differing perspectives within the healthcare sector, and sparked discussions about the need for more constructive dialogue and collaboration.

Health Secretary Teodora Herbosa and Senator Raffy Tulfo engaged in a heated argument during a Senate hearing on Tuesday.

item.content:encoded: Authorities arrested two alleged driver's license fixers in an entrapment operation in Barangay Pinyahan, Quezon City.

item.content:encoded: Authorities placed two towns in Marinduque under a state of calamity due to their high number of rabies cases.

item.title: PH, US national security advisers discuss China WPS actions
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Philippine, US, national security advisers, Chinese vessels, Philippine EEZ Summary: The Philippine and US national security advisers recently engaged in discussions concerning the aggressive actions of Chinese vessels in the Philippine Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). The National Security Council (NSC) revealed that these talks centered around the concerning behavior exhibited by Chinese vessels within Philippine waters. The presence of these Chinese vessels in the Philippine EEZ has raised tensions and poses potential threats to the region's security. The meeting aimed to address the escalating situation and strategize on potential diplomatic actions to address China's aggressive behavior. This collaboration between the Philippine and US security advisers highlights the importance of bilateral partnerships in ensuring regional stability and safeguarding territorial integrity. The discussions underscore the need for continued vigilance and cooperation among nations to uphold international maritime laws and norms in the South China Sea region.

Summary:

Philippine and US national security advisers discussed the aggressive actions of Chinese vessels in the Philippine EEZ, the National Security Council (NSC) said Tuesday.

item.title: SC: Smartphones, tablets prohibited in 2024 Shari"Ah Bar exams
item.content:encoded:
Supreme Court, smartphones, tablets, 2024, Shari'ah Summary: The Supreme Court has announced that the use of smartphones and tablets will be prohibited during the 2024 Shari'ah Bar examinations. This decision will impact aspiring lawyers taking the exam, as they will have to rely on traditional study methods and materials instead of digital devices. It is crucial for candidates to be aware of this rule and adequately prepare for the exam without the aid of technology. The Supreme Court's decision aims to maintain the integrity and fairness of the examinations, ensuring that all candidates are evaluated on a level playing field. As a result, test-takers must adhere to the guidelines set by the Court and refrain from using electronic devices during the exams. This rule reflects the Court's commitment to upholding the standards and principles of the Shari'ah Bar examinations, emphasizing the importance of individuals demonstrating their knowledge and skills without the assistance of modern technology.

The Supreme Court said that smartphones and tablets are prohibited during the 2024 Shari"ah Bar examinations

item.title: Rada Street closed from April 5 to 7 for Thai-PH food festival --Makati LGU
item.content:encoded:
April 5, Rada Street, Makati City, closed, Thailand-Philippines Street Food Festival
Rada Street in Makati City will be closed from April 5, 10 p.m., to April 7, 10 p.m. in connection with the Thailand-Philippines Street Food Festival, the local government announced. The closure is necessary for the successful conduct of the festival, which aims to showcase the vibrant street food culture of both Thailand and the Philippines. Visitors are advised to plan their travel routes accordingly to avoid inconvenience during the event. The festival promises to offer a wide array of delectable street food options from both countries, providing a unique culinary experience for attendees. This initiative highlights the rich food heritage shared between Thailand and the Philippines, fostering cultural exchange and appreciation among participants. The local government encourages everyone to support and enjoy the festivities while adhering to health and safety protocols in line with current guidelines.

Summary: - Rada Street in Makati City will be closed from April 5 to April 7 for the Thailand-Philippines Street Food Festival. - The closure aims to facilitate the successful conduct of the festival and showcase the vibrant street food culture of both countries. - Visitors should plan travel routes accordingly to avoid inconvenience during the event. - The festival will offer a variety of delicious street food options from Thailand and the Philippines, providing attendees with a unique culinary experience. - This initiative promotes cultural exchange and appreciation between the two countries, fostering a deeper understanding of their shared food heritage.

Rada Street in Makati City will be closed from April 5, 10 p.m., to April 7, 10 p.m. in connection with the Thailand-Philippines Street Food Festival, the local government said Tuesday.

item.title: PCG recovers Facebook page after hacking incident
item.content:encoded: The Philippine Coast Guard has fully recovered its Facebook page after another hacking incident.

item.content:encoded: The Division of City Schools of Manila has allowed teachers and students to wear comfortable clothes amid the sweltering heat in campuses.

item.title: 2nd tranche of Region II wage hike now in effect --DOLE
item.content:encoded: The P15 second trance of wage increase in Region II or Cagayan Valley has become effective on April 1, Unang Balita reported on Tuesday, citing the Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE).

item.title: Pedicab driver, patay sa pananaksak ng kapwa pedicab driver sa Maynila
item.content:encoded: Nasawi ang isang pedicab driver matapos siyang pagsasaksakin ng kapwa pedicab driver na kaniyang nakaalitan sa Sampaloc, Maynila.

item.title: Teodoro warns of China efforts to 'refocus' West PH Sea debate
item.content:encoded:
alleged, China, West Philippine Sea, Gilberto Teodoro Jr., warning Summary: Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro Jr. warned of China's alleged efforts to change the course of the debate regarding the West Philippine Sea (WPS). He raised concerns about a supposed "gentlemen's agreement" between China and former President Rodrigo Duterte. Teodoro highlighted the need to remain vigilant and uphold national sovereignty in the face of China's actions in the WPS. The warning comes amidst ongoing tensions and disputes over territorial claims in the region. Teodoro emphasized the importance of fostering strong diplomatic relations with neighboring countries to address maritime security challenges effectively. The Philippine government's stance on defending its territorial integrity and rights in the WPS remains resolute despite attempts to influence the narrative. Teodoro's words serve as a reminder of the complex geopolitical dynamics at play in the South China Sea and the need for constant vigilance to protect national interests.

Summary:

Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro Jr. on Monday warned of China's alleged efforts to change the course of the debate regarding the West Philippine Sea (WPS), in light of the supposed "gentlemen's agreement" between China and former President Rodrigo Duterte.

item.title: DOH to schools: Prioritize condition of students amid extreme heat
item.content:encoded:
DOH, schools, students, face-to-face classes, hot weather Summary: The Department of Health (DOH) is urging schools to assess students' conditions and consider if they can attend face-to-face classes during hot weather. It is crucial for schools to prioritize the well-being of students, particularly in extreme weather conditions. Schools play a crucial role in ensuring the safety and comfort of students, especially during very hot temperatures. By taking into account the individual needs and vulnerabilities of students, schools can make informed decisions about conducting face-to-face classes during such weather conditions. It is important for schools to be mindful of the impact of hot weather on students and to create a safe and conducive learning environment for everyone.

The Department of Health (DOH) on Tuesday urged schools to take into consideration the conditions of students and to determine if they could attend face-to-face classes during the very hot weather.

item.title: QC starts building elevated walkway connecting memorial circle, wildlife park
item.content:encoded:
Quezon City government, elevated walkway, Ninoy Aquino Parks and Wildlife Center, Quezon Memorial Circle, construction

Summary:
The Quezon City government is currently in the process of constructing an elevated walkway that will connect the Ninoy Aquino Parks and Wildlife Center with the Quezon Memorial Circle. This infrastructure project aims to provide a safer and more convenient pedestrian pathway for residents and visitors. The elevated walkway will enhance connectivity between the two popular destinations in Quezon City, allowing people to easily access and enjoy the attractions and amenities in the area. Once completed, the walkway is expected to improve pedestrian mobility and reduce traffic congestion in the vicinity. This initiative demonstrates the city government's commitment to promoting sustainable and accessible urban development.

The Quezon City government has started constructing an elevated walkway that will link the Ninoy Aquino Parks and Wildlife Center and the Quezon Memorial Circle.

item.title: Makati files complaint vs. Taguig execs for alleged graft, neglect of duty
item.content:encoded: Makati City has lodged a complaint against three Taguig City government employees before the Office of the Ombudsman for supposed neglect of duty.

item.title: 28 barangays under state of calamity as Cebu City faces water crisis amid El Niño
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: State of calamity, 28 barangays, Cebu City, El Niño phenomenon, impact
Summary:
A state of calamity has been declared in 28 barangays in Cebu City due to the severe impact of the El Niño phenomenon. The declaration was made to address the effects of the prolonged dry spell and water shortage in the region. The state of calamity allows the local government to access funds and resources to provide assistance to affected residents. The El Niño phenomenon has caused drought conditions, affecting agricultural crops and water sources in the area. Crops have withered and water sources have dried up, leading to concerns about food security and access to clean water. The declaration of a state of calamity is a necessary step to mitigate the effects of the drought and provide relief to the affected communities.

State of calamity has been declared in 28 barangays in Cebu City due to the impact of the El Niño phenomenon.

item.title: Marcos orders creation of organizing council for PH hosting of ASEAN 2026
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: President Marcos, national organizing council, Philippines, ASEAN meetings, 2026 Summary: President Marcos has issued a directive for the establishment of a national organizing council to oversee the preparations for the Philippines' hosting of the ASEAN meetings in 2026. This council will be responsible for coordinating various aspects of the event to ensure its success. The meetings are expected to bring together leaders from ASEAN member countries to discuss regional issues and strengthen cooperation. The Philippines will play a crucial role in facilitating these discussions and showcasing its capabilities as a host nation. President Marcos's decision underscores the government's commitment to upholding its responsibilities as an active member of the ASEAN community. The establishment of the council reflects the country's dedication to promoting unity and collaboration among ASEAN nations for mutual progress and development. With adequate planning and coordination, the Philippines is poised to host a successful series of ASEAN meetings in 2026.

Summary: President Marcos has instructed the creation of a national organizing council in the Philippines to oversee the hosting of the ASEAN meetings in 2026. The council's main focus will be on ensuring the smooth coordination and execution of the event, which will bring together leaders from ASEAN member countries to address regional issues and strengthen cooperation. By taking on this role, the Philippines aims to demonstrate its capabilities as a responsible and capable host nation within the ASEAN community. This initiative highlights the government's dedication to fulfilling its commitments and fostering unity and collaboration among ASEAN nations for shared progress and prosperity. Through careful planning and effective governance, the Philippines is well-positioned to host a successful series of ASEAN meetings in 2026.

President Marcos has ordered the creation of a national organizing council for the Philippines' hosting of the ASEAN meetings in 2026.

item.title: TRB starts probe into malfunctioning RFID
item.content:encoded:
TRB, investigation, faulty RFID system, traffic jams, expressways

The Toll Regulatory Board (TRB) has initiated a probe into the malfunctioning radio frequency identification (RFID) system that led to significant traffic congestion on various expressways over the Holy Week holiday. The investigation aims to identify the root cause of the system failure, which resulted in long queues and delays for motorists. The faulty RFID system disrupted the flow of traffic and inconvenienced travelers during the peak travel period. TRB is seeking to address the issues promptly and prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. The investigation will focus on determining the areas of improvement needed to ensure the seamless operation of the RFID system and enhance overall traffic management on expressways. The TRB's efforts are geared towards enhancing the efficiency and reliability of toll systems for the convenience of the commuting public.

Summary:

The Toll Regulatory Board (TRB) has launched an investigation into the faulty radio frequency identification (RFID) system which caused traffic jams in several expressways during the Holy Week break.

item.title: North Korea fires suspected intermediate-range ballistic missile
item.content:encoded: North Korea fired a suspected intermediate-range ballistic missile into the sea off its east coast on Tuesday, South Korea's military said, in a move that sparked immediate condemnation from the prime minister of Japan.

item.title: Israel airstrike on Gaza kills foreign aid workers --Hamas-run media office
item.content:encoded: At least five employees of the World Central Kitchen non-governmental organization, including foreigners, were killed in an Israeli airstrike on Gaza, the Hamas-run Gaza government media office said late on Monday.

item.title: Marcos orders creation of right-of-way committee for railway projects
item.content:encoded: President Marcos has directed the creation of an inter-agency committee that aims to streamline the process of land acquisition for all the railway projects across the country.

item.title: DOE applies measures to avert power interruptions amid El Niño, dry season
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: power sector, measures, avoid, power interruptions, El Niño
Summary: The Department of Energy (DOE) has announced that the power sector is taking steps to prevent potential power outages in response to the impact of the El Niño phenomenon and dry season in the Philippines. Various measures are being implemented to ensure the stability and reliability of the country's power supply during this challenging period. The DOE is closely monitoring the situation and working closely with power providers to address any potential challenges that may arise. By proactively addressing the impact of El Niño and the dry season on the power sector, the DOE aims to prevent power interruptions and ensure a continuous and reliable supply of electricity for the country. This proactive approach demonstrates the government's commitment to ensuring the resilience of the power sector in the face of challenging environmental conditions.

Summary:

The power sector is implementing measures to avoid possible power interruptions amid the impact of the El Niño phenomenon and dry season on the country, the Department of Energy (DOE) said Tuesday.

item.title: Garin's advice to women amid hot weather: Don't wear underwear at home
item.content:encoded:
advised, fungal infection, hot weather, women, underwear Summary: House Deputy Majority Leader and Iloilo Representative Janette Garin has advised women to avoid wearing underwear, especially in hot weather, to prevent fungal infections. Garin suggests that women refrain from wearing underwear while at home. This precaution can help reduce the risk of developing fungal infections in the summer months. By allowing the area to breathe and stay dry, women can maintain better hygiene and prevent the growth of fungi in warm and moist conditions. Garin's advice aims to promote good health practices and reduce the chances of skin irritations or infections during hot weather.

To avoid fungal infection amid the hot weather, House Deputy Majority Leader and Iloilo Representative Janette Garin has advised women not to wear underwear especially if they are just in the confines of their homes.

item.title: Trump posts $175-M bond in civil fraud case, averting asset seizures
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Donald Trump, bond, New York, civil fraud case, asset seizures Summary: Donald Trump posted a $175 million bond in his New York civil fraud case on Monday to prevent asset seizures by state authorities. By posting the bond, Trump was able to avoid having his business empire hobbled. This legal action comes after Trump and his company were accused of misleading investors and lenders about the value of their real estate assets. The bond allows Trump to continue operating his businesses without fear of seizure, providing a temporary reprieve to his financial interests. The case is ongoing and its outcome will have significant implications for Trump's future business dealings in New York. The bond is a substantial amount and demonstrates the seriousness of the allegations against Trump and the potential consequences he faces if found guilty. Overall, this legal maneuver allows Trump to retain control over his assets while the civil fraud case progresses in court.

Summary:

Donald Trump posted a $175 million bond in his New York civil fraud case on Monday, averting asset seizures by state authorities that could have hobbled the former US president"s business empire.

item.title: Closure of Mt. Apo Natural Park extended due to El Niño
item.content:encoded: All trails and access points to Mt. Apo Natural Park for trekking and camping activities are closed until April 30, 2024.

item.title: Israeli airstrike kills five from World Central Kitchen, says Hamas-run media
item.content:encoded: At least five employees from the World Central Kitchen were killed by an Israeli airstrike in central Gaza's Deir al-Balah, the Hamas-run Gaza Government Media Office announced late on Monday.

item.title: Maryland opens temporary channel at collapsed Baltimore bridge site
item.content:encoded:
Maryland, temporary channel, Baltimore bridge, vessel traffic, container ship Summary: Maryland has opened a temporary channel on the northeast side of the collapsed Baltimore bridge to allow vessel traffic to pass around the stuck container ship. Governor Wes Moore announced this development on Monday. The channel has been created to ensure the smooth flow of maritime traffic in the wake of the bridge collapse. The container ship had been blocking the waterway following the disaster, and the opening of the temporary channel provides a workaround for vessels to navigate through the area. This initiative aims to mitigate disruptions caused by the bridge collapse and facilitate the movement of boats in the affected region. Authorities are working diligently to address the aftermath of the incident and maintain the functionality of the water route.

The U.S. state of Maryland has opened a temporary channel on the northeast side of the collapsed Baltimore bridge, allowing vessel traffic around the container ship stuck at the disaster site, Governor Wes Moore said on Monday.

item.title: Magnitude 6.1 earthquake strikes northern Japan
item.content:encoded:
Earthquake, magnitude, Iwate, Aomori, Japan Summary:

An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 6.1 struck Iwate and Aomori prefectures in northern Japan on Tuesday, as reported by the Japan Meteorological Agency. The earthquake caused widespread shaking in the region, leading to concerns about potential damage to buildings and infrastructure. No immediate reports of injuries or major damage were received following the earthquake, but authorities are continuing to assess the situation. The tremor serves as a reminder of Japan's vulnerability to seismic activity due to its location along the Pacific Ring of Fire. Monitoring and early warning systems in place helped to provide advance notice of the earthquake, allowing residents to take necessary precautions. Further monitoring and assessment will be conducted to determine the full impact of the earthquake on the affected areas.

An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 6.1 hit Iwate and Aomori prefectures in northern Japan on Tuesday, the Japan Meteorological Agency said.

item.title: Israel bombs Iran embassy in Syria, Iranian commanders among dead
item.content:encoded:
Israeli warplanes, embassy, Iran, Syria, bombing

Israel conducted airstrikes on Iran's embassy in Syria, resulting in the deaths of seven military advisers, three of whom were senior commanders. This attack signifies an escalation in the ongoing conflict between Israel and its regional adversaries. The bombing targeted Iranian personnel in Syria, marking a direct military confrontation between the two countries. The incident underscores the mounting tensions in the region and the potential for further violence. Iran condemned the attack as a blatant act of aggression by Israel and vowed to retaliate. The strike on the embassy highlights the complex dynamics and power struggles at play in the Middle East, with multiple actors vying for control and influence. The repercussions of this attack are likely to have far-reaching consequences for the region's stability and security.

Summary:

Suspected Israeli warplanes bombed Iran's embassy in Syria on Monday, a marked escalation in a war pitting Israel against its regional adversaries, and Tehran said the strike killed seven military advisers including three senior commanders.

item.title: Texas, CDC say bird influenza detected in person exposed to dairy cattle
item.content:encoded:
Texas, U.S., CDC, avian influenza, dairy cows
Summary:
A human case of avian influenza has been reported in Texas, with the individual believed to have had contact with infected dairy cows. This marks a concerning development in the spread of the virus, as it demonstrates potential transmission from animals to humans. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is closely monitoring the situation and working to prevent further cases. The infected person's condition and potential spread of the virus are key points of concern. It is crucial to take necessary precautions to contain the outbreak and protect public health. The case highlights the importance of monitoring and controlling infections in animals to prevent the transmission of dangerous viruses to humans. The health authorities in Texas are working to investigate the source of the infection and implement measures to prevent further spread.

Texas and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on Monday reported a human case of avian influenza in a person who had contact with dairy cows presumed to be infected with the virus.

item.title: 8-year-old boy drowns after being left unwatched while swimming
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: eight-year-old boy, drowned, unwatched, open water, swimming
Summary:
An eight-year-old boy tragically drowned while swimming in open water after being left unattended by adults. The boy, whose name has not been released, was left unwatched as he swam, leading to the tragic accident. The incident serves as a stark reminder of the importance of adult supervision when children are near water bodies. The boy's family and the community are devastated by the loss, and authorities are investigating the circumstances that led to the tragedy. This heartbreaking event highlights the dangers of swimming in open water without proper supervision, especially for young children. It is crucial for adults to ensure the safety of children around water and to always be vigilant while they are swimming. The boy's untimely death has sparked discussions about water safety and the need for increased awareness and prevention measures to avoid similar tragedies in the future.

Summary:

An eight-year-old boy drowned after he was left unwatched by grown-ups while swimming in open water.

item.title: Online selling feud seen as 22-year-old woman stabbed to death in Davao City
item.content:encoded:
stabbed, death, woman, Davao City, suspects Summary: Two suspects riding in tandem stabbed and killed a 22-year-old woman in Davao City. The incident occurred over the weekend, as reported by Jandi Esteban of GMA Regional TV One Mindanao on “24 Oras.” The victim was fatally wounded by the suspects, who swiftly carried out the attack. The suspects managed to escape the scene after the brutal stabbing, leaving the woman to succumb to her injuries. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, and authorities are conducting a thorough investigation to apprehend the perpetrators. The tragic incident has left the community shocked and concerned about the safety and security of residents in the area. The identity of the victim has not been released, pending notification of her next of kin. The authorities are urging anyone with information about the suspects or the incident to come forward and assist in bringing them to justice.Residents are advised to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity to the authorities immediately.

Summary:

Suspects who were riding in tandem stabbed to death a 22-year-old woman in Davao City over the weekend, Jandi Esteban of GMA Regional TV One Mindanao reported on “24 Oras.”

item.title: Garin pushes vaccination catch-up plan vs. pertussis, other illnesses
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: government, catch-up plan, vaccinate, Filipinos, pertussis

The government should implement a catch-up plan to vaccinate Filipinos and strengthen their bodily defenses against pertussis and other illnesses, as suggested by Iloilo Representative Janette Garin. This plan will help protect the population from potentially deadly diseases and prevent outbreaks. By increasing access to vaccines and promoting immunization, the government can ensure that citizens are better equipped to fight off infections and stay healthy. Vaccination programs have been proven to be an effective way to prevent the spread of diseases and protect public health. It is crucial for the government to prioritize the health and well-being of its citizens by increasing vaccination coverage and promoting awareness about the importance of immunization. With a comprehensive catch-up plan in place, the government can help prevent future health crises and ensure a healthier future for all Filipinos.

Summary: The government should implement a catch-up plan to vaccinate Filipinos and strengthen their bodily defenses against pertussis and other illnesses. Vaccination programs have been proven to be an effective way to prevent the spread of diseases and protect public health. By increasing access to vaccines and promoting immunization, the government can ensure that citizens are better equipped to fight off infections and stay healthy. It is crucial for the government to prioritize the health and well-being of its citizens by increasing vaccination coverage and promoting awareness about the importance of immunization. With a comprehensive catch-up plan in place, the government can help prevent future health crises and ensure a healthier future for all Filipinos.

The government should implement a catch-up plan to vaccinate as many Filipinos and strengthen their bodily defenses against pertussis and other illnesses, Iloilo Representative Janette Garin said.

item.title: Mga bingi, kayang makarinig sa pamamagitan ng hilot?
item.content:encoded:
15-year-old, Gian, unable to hear, miracle, mother's prayer, group of healers Summary: - 15-year-old Gian is unable to hear. - A mother prays for a miracle for her son to regain his hearing. - They learn about a group of healers who claim to restore hearing through massage. - The mother is amazed by the teenager's reaction to the healing session. - The healers successfully restore Gian's hearing, bringing joy and relief to the family.

Summary:

Bata pa lang, hindi na umano nakadidinig ang 15-anyos na si Gian. Kaya ipinagdarasal ng kaniyang ina na dumating sana ang panahon na magkaroon ng himala na makadinig ang kaniyang anak. Hanggang sa nalaman nila ang tungkol sa isang grupo ng manghihilot na kaya raw magbalik ng pandinig ng mga bingi sa pamamagitan lang ng hilot, at namangha siya sa naging reaksyon ng binatilyo.

item.title: Baguio City govt confirms 5 pertussis cases
item.content:encoded:
Baguio City, government, pertussis, whooping cough, cases Summary: - The Baguio City government has confirmed five cases of pertussis (whooping cough) between Feb. 19 and March 27. - The confirmed cases are being closely monitored and treated to prevent further spread of the disease. - Health officials are urging the public to practice good hygiene and get vaccinated to protect themselves and others from pertussis. - Pertussis is a highly contagious respiratory infection that can be particularly dangerous for infants and young children. - The city government is working to raise awareness about the importance of vaccination and early detection of pertussis to prevent outbreaks.

Summary:

The Baguio City government has confirmed five cases of pertussis or whooping cough from Feb. 19 to March 27.

item.title: Duterte had no deal with China over Ayungin --Panelo
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Rodrigo Duterte, China, agreement, BRP Sierra Madre, Ayungin Shoal Summary: Former President Rodrigo Duterte did not make any agreement with China regarding the maintenance of the BRP Sierra Madre, which is stranded in the Ayungin Shoal. A member of his cabinet clarified that there was no such commitment from Duterte to China. The BRP Sierra Madre serves as a Philippine military outpost in the disputed South China Sea and has been strategically placed to assert the country's territorial claims. The clarification comes amid concerns about Duterte's foreign policy and his stance on territorial disputes with China. The stranded vessel symbolizes the Philippines' assertion of sovereignty in the region and the commitment to protect its territorial interests. The Philippine government's decision to maintain the BRP Sierra Madre demonstrates its resolve to safeguard its maritime territories despite geopolitical pressures. The clarification addresses speculations about Duterte's alleged concessions to China and reaffirms the country's commitment to upholding its sovereignty in the South China Sea.

Summary:

Former President Rodrigo Duterte didn't enter into any agreement with China not to maintain BRP Sierra Madre which is aground in the Ayungin Shoal, a member of his cabinet has said.

item.title: DA to vaccinate dogs, cats to curb rabies cases in Marinduque livestock
item.content:encoded: The Department of Agriculture (DA) said Monday it will begin to vaccinate dogs and cats in Marinduque in an effort to curb the cases of rabies infections among livestock in the province.

item.title: Face-to-face class sa ilang paaralan, suspendido sa Martes, April 2, 2024
item.content:encoded: Dahil pa rin sa mainit na panahon, ilang paaralan at lokal na pamahalaan ang nagsuspinde ng face-to-face class sa Martes, April 2, 2024.

item.title: Inmate designs 'arcade-like' game at NBP
item.content:encoded: A person deprived of liberty (PDL) at the New Bilibid Prison (NBP) created an arcade game inside the detention facility, which he hopes to be a source of livelihood for prisoners.

item.title: Pagsalpok ng motorsiklo sa lumilikong kotse, nahuli-cam sa Pangasinan
item.content:encoded:
Calasiao, Pangasinan, accident, motorcycle, car Summary: Two individuals riding a motorcycle were injured after colliding with a turning car in Calasiao, Pangasinan. The accident occurred when the motorcycle crashed into the car as it was making a turn, resulting in injuries to both riders. The collision highlights the importance of caution and awareness on the road, particularly at intersections and during turns. The injured individuals were promptly attended to and taken to a nearby hospital for medical treatment. Authorities are investigating the incident to determine the cause of the collision and any necessary actions to prevent similar accidents in the future. The incident serves as a reminder for all motorists to prioritize safety and follow traffic rules to avoid accidents and ensure the well-being of everyone on the road.

Summary:

Sugatan ang dalawang sakay ng motorsiklo nang sumalpok sila sa papalikong kotse sa Calasiao, Pangasinan.

item.title: P181-M lotto jackpot prize eludes winners in first April 2024 draw
item.content:encoded:
lotto draw, winners, Monday, Holy Week break, no winners
Summary: After the Holy Week break, the lotto draws on Monday did not produce any winners. Both of the big lotto draws had no lucky ticket holders, meaning the jackpot prizes remain unrewarded. Players were left disappointed as they missed out on the chance to win a substantial amount of money. The lack of winners could lead to even larger jackpots in the following draws, as the prize money rolls over to the next draw. This outcome serves as a reminder of the unpredictable nature of lotto games and the slim odds of winning the jackpot. Despite the anticipation and excitement surrounding the draws, players will have to wait for another opportunity to try their luck and potentially become the next big winner.

There were no winners of either of the big lotto draws on Monday, the first after the Holy Week break.

item.title: 22-anyos na babae, patay matapos saksakin sa leeg sa Davao City
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: 22-year-old woman, stabbed in neck, near police station, online selling dispute, Davao City Summary: A 22-year-old woman was fatally stabbed in the neck near a police station in Davao City, and the suspected motive behind the crime is believed to be a dispute related to online selling. The victim succumbed to her injuries on the scene. The incident took place in close proximity to the police station, raising concerns about the brazenness of the attack. Authorities are investigating the case and pursuing leads to apprehend the perpetrator responsible for the heinous crime. The tragic event serves as a grim reminder of the dangers that can arise from online transactions and disputes, highlighting the need for heightened awareness and caution when engaging in such activities. The community is shaken by the senseless loss of a young life and calls for justice for the victim. The police are working diligently to solve the case and bring the perpetrator to account for their actions. The incident underscores the importance of ensuring safety measures in online transactions to prevent such tragic outcomes.

Summary:

Patay ang isang 22-anyos na babae matapos siyang saksakin sa leeg malapit sa police station ng Davao City. Ang hinihinalang ugat ng krimen, away sa online selling.

item.title: Mahigit 200 kilong tuna, nalambat sa Pasuquin, Ilocos Norte
item.content:encoded:
mangingisda, Pasuquin, Ilocos Norte, tuna, biyaya Summary:
Mangingisda in Pasuquin, Ilocos Norte, are grateful for the over 200-kilo tuna they caught, considering it a significant blessing.

Itinuturing malaking biyaya ng mga mangingisda sa Pasuquin, Ilocos Norte ang mahigit 200 kilo ng tuna na kanilang nalambat.

item.title: Senate resolution urges diplomatic measures amid China harassment
item.content:encoded:
Resolution, government, legal, diplomatic, countermeasures
A resolution was filed in the Senate urging the government to take legal and diplomatic actions against China due to ongoing tensions in the West Philippine Sea. The resolution calls for the implementation of all available legal and diplomatic measures in response to China's activities in the disputed region. It reaffirms the Philippines' commitment to upholding its sovereignty and territorial integrity and expresses concern over China's aggressive actions in the area. The resolution seeks to protect the country's sovereign rights in the West Philippine Sea and ensure peace and stability in the region. It emphasizes the importance of resolving disputes through peaceful means in accordance with international law and the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The resolution highlights the need for the government to defend the country's interests and uphold its obligations as a responsible member of the international community.

Summary: A resolution urging the government to take legal and diplomatic actions against China in response to tensions in the West Philippine Sea was filed in the Senate. It reaffirms the Philippines' commitment to sovereignty and territorial integrity and expresses concern over China's aggressive actions in the region. The resolution seeks to protect the country's sovereign rights and ensure peace and stability in the area. It emphasizes the importance of resolving disputes peacefully and in accordance with international law. The government is urged to defend the country's interests and uphold its obligations as a responsible member of the international community.

A resolution urging the government to exert all legal and diplomatic countermeasures against China amid continued tension in the West Philippine Sea was filed in the Senate.

item.title: Diver, kinagat sa ulo ng dambuhalang isda na tila naasar sa kaniya sa China
item.content:encoded:
diver, aquarium, China, sturgeon, altercation Summary: In a large aquarium in China, a diver was suddenly attacked by a giant fish while feeding the fish. Prior to the attack, it was discovered that there was a previous altercation between the diver and the sturgeon fish over a bag. The diver was feeding the fish when the sturgeon fish unexpectedly grabbed him by the head. This incident highlights the dangers that divers face while interacting with marine animals in contained environments like aquariums. It also sheds light on the territorial behavior of certain species of fish, such as the sturgeon, when it comes to defending their territory or resources. The diver's quick thinking and survival instincts likely saved him from serious injury or worse during the encounter. The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of understanding and respecting the boundaries of marine life, even in controlled environments.

Biglang sinakmal sa ulo ng isang dambuhalang isda ang isang diver na nagpapakain sa mga isda sa loob ng isang malaking aquarium sa China. Pero bago ang pananakmal, napag-alaman na may pinag-agawan muna na bag ang diver at ang isda na isang sturgeon.

item.title: Zubiri says he's mulling retirement
item.content:encoded:
Senate President Juan Miguel Zubiri, no longer run, public office, considering retiring, politics
Senate President Juan Miguel Zubiri has stated that he will not run for any public office in the future and is contemplating retirement from politics. This decision by Zubiri marks a significant shift in his career trajectory as a prominent political figure in the Philippines. Despite his current role as Senate President, Zubiri seems to be prioritizing a departure from the political arena. This development signals a potential end to Zubiri's tenure in public service and his long-standing involvement in the country's political landscape. Zubiri's announcement of his intentions to step away from politics comes as a surprise to many observers, given his established position and influence within the government. As he looks towards the possibility of retirement, Zubiri's decision reflects a personal choice to pursue a different path outside of the political sphere.

Summary:

Senate President Juan Miguel Zubiri reiterated Monday that he will no longer run for public office and is considering retiring from politics.

item.title: PH-India to pursue deeper bilateral relations
item.content:encoded:
Philippines, India, bilateral defense relations, Department of National Defense, credible defense posture
Summary: The Philippines and India are looking to enhance their bilateral defense ties, particularly in response to escalating tensions in the West Philippine Sea (WPS). The Department of National Defense (DND) of the Philippines is focusing on developing a robust defense posture amidst the current challenges. Strengthening defense cooperation with India is seen as a strategic move in this regard. Both countries aim to work together closely to address the regional security concerns in the WPS and beyond. The collaboration between the two nations is expected to enhance their defense capabilities and foster greater security in the region. As the maritime disputes in the WPS continue to escalate, a strong defense partnership between the Philippines and India is crucial in maintaining stability and peace in the region.

The Philippines and India are poised to strengthen their bilateral defense relations as the Department of National Defense (DND) develops a credible defense posture amid heightened tensions in the West Philippine Sea (WPS).

item.title: Babae sa Cebu, bakit kaya sobrang lumobo ang tiyan?
item.content:encoded:
57-year-old woman, Barili, Cebu, bloated stomach, difficulty moving, difficulty sleeping Summary: A 57-year-old woman residing in a remote area in Barili, Cebu is experiencing difficulty in movement and sleep due to her excessively bloated stomach. The exact cause of her condition is unclear, but it is likely attributed to various factors such as poor diet, lack of exercise, or underlying health issues. The woman's quality of life is significantly impacted as she struggles to carry out daily activities and get adequate rest. Seeking medical attention is crucial to determine the root cause of her bloated stomach and explore potential treatment options. With proper diagnosis and intervention, there is a possibility of addressing the woman's condition and improving her overall well-being. It is essential for her to consult healthcare professionals for an accurate assessment and personalized care plan to alleviate her discomfort and restore her ability to move and sleep comfortably.

Hirap kumilos at hindi makatulog nang maayos ang isang 57-anyos na babae sa isang liblib na lugar sa Barili, Cebu dahil sa sobrang laki ng kaniyang tiyan. Ano kaya ang dahilan nito at maaari pa kaya itong malunasan?

item.title: ACT: 77% of NCR public school teachers say classroom heat intolerable
item.content:encoded: The ACT-National Capital Region Union said that their survey found that 77% of NCR public school teachers could not bear the extreme heat in classrooms.

item.title: Ilang paaralan, walang pasok dahil sa matinding init ng panahon
item.content:encoded: Sinuspinde ang klase sa ilang eskuwelahan sa bansa ngayong Lunes, Abril 1, 2024, dahil sa matinding init ng panahon.

item.title: Lalaking nanood ng prusisyon sa Camarines Norte, patay sa pananaksak; 3 pa, sugatan
item.content:encoded: Isang 22-anyos na lalaki ang nasawi sa pananaksak, at tatlong iba pa ang sugatan matapos magkainitan ang dalawang grupo ng kalalakihan sa Talisay, Camarines Norte.

item.title: BI arrests 4 suspects behind proliferation of illegal PH docs
item.content:encoded: The Bureau of Immigration (BI) on Monday announced that four Chinese suspected to be behind the proliferation of fraudulently-acquired government-issued IDs and documents were arrested in Palawan, including the alleged leader.

item.title: MMDA to impose fines vs 2 contractors after unfinished EDSA projects cause heavy traffic
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: contractors, fines, EDSA, traffic, MMDA
Summary: Contractors along EDSA are facing fines for failing to complete their projects, leading to heavy traffic. The two contractors, whose identities were not disclosed, caused significant disruptions along the major thoroughfare. This resulted in immense inconvenience for motorists and communities reliant on the passage for transportation. The Metropolitan Manila Development Authority (MMDA) intervened to address the issue, holding the non-compliant contractors accountable for their actions. The fines levied against the contractors signify the MMDA's commitment to maintaining order and efficiency on EDSA, a crucial artery in the transportation network of Metro Manila. The consequences faced by these contractors serve as a warning to others regarding the importance of timely project completion and adherence to regulations to prevent disruptions to the public.

Summary:

Two contractors are facing fines after they failed to complete their projects along EDSA that caused heavy traffic along the major thoroughfare, the MMDA said Monday.

item.title: Pulse Asia poll showing 8% of Pinoys favor Cha-cha proves need for plebiscite --House leader
item.content:encoded:
Pulse Asia survey, Filipinos, Charter change, plebiscite, House of Representatives
Summary:
The Pulse Asia survey revealed that only 8% of Filipinos support Charter change (Cha-cha), emphasizing the necessity for a plebiscite, according to a House of Representatives leader. This low level of support underscores the importance of gaining popular approval through a plebiscite before proceeding with any significant constitutional amendments. This data points to potential challenges in advancing Cha-cha without ensuring public consent. The survey results suggest a lack of widespread backing for Cha-cha among Filipinos, prompting the call for a plebiscite to gauge public opinion accurately. The House of Representatives acknowledges the need for a plebiscite to ensure that any proposed changes to the Constitution have broad-based support from the Filipino populace.

The Pulse Asia survey showing only 8% of Filipinos favor Charter change (Cha-cha) only highlights the need for a plebiscite, a leader of the House of Representatives said Monday.

item.title: Gen. Rommel Francisco Marbil, napili ni Pres. Marcos na bagong PNP chief
item.content:encoded:
Marcos, Francisco Marbil, Philippine National Police, PNP, appointment Summary: President Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos appointed Police General Francisco Marbil as the new head of the Philippine National Police (PNP). Marbil, an experienced police officer, will be tasked with leading the country's police force in maintaining peace and order. His appointment comes at a critical time for the PNP, as they face increasing challenges in addressing criminality and maintaining public safety. Marbil's leadership skills and dedication to serving the Filipino people are expected to guide the PNP in fulfilling its mandate of protecting and serving the nation. As the new PNP chief, Marbil vows to uphold the rule of law, promote integrity within the police force, and work towards building stronger partnerships with communities to address crime effectively. President Marcos expressed confidence in Marbil's abilities and commitment to improving the PNP's performance, ensuring that the country's law enforcement agency remains responsive and proactive in safeguarding the welfare of the Filipino people.

Napili ni Pangulong Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos si Police General Francisco Marbil bilang bagong pinuno ng Philippine National Police (PNP).

item.title: PH response to Chinese aggression in WPS not 'purely military" -- task force
item.content:encoded: The planned countermeasures of the Philippines to China"s aggressive actions in the West Philippine Sea (WPS) are not purely military, the National Task Force (NTF) for the WPS said on Monday.

item.title: CA affirms conviction of 7 Abu Sayyaf members
item.content:encoded: The Court of Appeals (CA) has affirmed the decision of a Taguig court that found seven members of the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group guilty for the murder of an alleged military asset in 2007.

item.title: PH policies will not affect China's maritime rights --Chinese foreign ministry
item.content:encoded: A China foreign ministry spokesperson said on Monday that no matter what policies the Philippines rolls out, it cannot affect China's sovereignty and maritime rights.

item.title: DA monitoring rabies infection among cattle in Marinduque
item.content:encoded: The Department of Agriculture has received reports that cattle in the province of Marinduque have been infected with rabies.

item.title: Marcos calls for a more efficient PNP under new leadership
item.content:encoded: President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr. on Monday called on the Philippine National Police to be more efficient in the performance of its duties.

item.title: DA: No cases of foot and mouth disease in PH
item.content:encoded:
Philippines, Department of Agriculture, foot and mouth disease, animals, cases Summary: The Department of Agriculture in the Philippines reported on Monday that there are still no cases of foot and mouth disease among animals in the country. This announcement is reassuring news for farmers and the livestock industry. The monitoring efforts by the Department of Agriculture seem to be effective in preventing the spread of the disease. In a time where diseases affecting animals can have significant economic and health repercussions, this update provides a sense of relief. It signifies that current protocols and measures in place are working well to safeguard the health and well-being of the animal population in the Philippines. This ongoing vigilance and prompt reporting by the Department of Agriculture will contribute to maintaining the safety and security of the agricultural sector.

Summary:

The Department of Agriculture on Monday reported that there are still no cases of foot and mouth disease among animals in the Philippines.

item.title: Marcos can rescind Duterte"s agreement with China, ex-SC justice says
item.content:encoded:
agreement, China, President Duterte, Justice Jardeleza, President Marcos Jr. Summary:

Retired Supreme Court Justice Francis Jardeleza emphasized that President Marcos Jr. has the authority to rescind the agreement entered into by former President Duterte with China, as he is now the primary architect of foreign policy. This highlights the potential for a shift in foreign relations between the Philippines and China under the new leadership. The assertion underscores the importance of the current president in shaping diplomatic decisions and agreements with other nations. The role of the chief architect of foreign policy is crucial in determining the direction of international relations and partnerships. With the power to rescind agreements, President Marcos Jr. holds significant influence over the country's engagement with China and other countries, marking a potential shift in foreign policy priorities.

Though former President Rodrigo Duterte entered into an agreement with China, retired Supreme Court Justice Francis Jardeleza on Monday stressed that President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. can rescind it as he is now the chief architect of foreign policy.

item.title: 'CEO" of auto trading company arrested for allegedly scamming clients
item.content:encoded:
CEO, auto trading, arrested, Manila police, estafa
The chief executive officer of an auto trading firm was arrested by Manila police after clients reported him for estafa. The man, whose name was not disclosed, was accused of scamming his clients and operating a fraudulent auto trading business. The clients claimed that they had invested large sums of money with the firm but never received any returns. The CEO was taken into custody by authorities and will face legal charges for his alleged crimes. The incident has caused uproar among the victims, who are seeking justice and hoping to recover their lost investments.

Summary: The CEO of an auto trading firm in Manila was arrested by police following estafa complaints from clients. He allegedly scammed investors and operated a fraudulent business, leading to his apprehension and impending legal action. The victims are demanding justice and aiming to recoup their lost funds.

A man, who was said to be the chief executive officer of an auto trading firm, was arrested by the Manila police after his clients filed estafa cases against him.

item.title: 783 inmates released in March --BuCor

barangays, Imus, Cavite, water service interruption, scheduled, Maynilad Water Services Inc. item.title: Canals, irrigation reservoirs drying up in South Cotabato due to hot weather
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: canals, irrigation reservoirs, drying up, Santo Niño, South Cotabato

The hot weather in Santo Niño, South Cotabato is causing some canals and irrigation reservoirs to dry up. This has resulted in a shortage of water for agricultural purposes, affecting the local farmers and their crops. The lack of water has also impacted the overall ecosystem in the area. The drying up of these water sources is a concerning issue that needs to be addressed promptly to prevent further consequences on the agriculture and environment in the region. Local authorities and stakeholders are urged to take immediate actions to mitigate the effects of the drying canals and reservoirs and ensure sustainable water management practices for the future. The situation serves as a reminder of the importance of conserving and preserving water resources, especially in regions prone to extreme weather conditions like Santo Niño. Cooperation and support from the community are essential in finding solutions to maintain the water supply for the well-being of the residents and the environment.

Summary:
Hot weather in Santo Niño, South Cotabato has led to the drying up of canals and irrigation reservoirs, causing a water shortage for agriculture and affecting the local ecosystem. Immediate action is needed to address this issue and ensure sustainable water management practices in the region.

Some canals and irrigation reservoirs have been drying up in Santo Niño, South Cotabato due to the hot weather.

customers, Maynilad Water Services Inc., Caloocan City, service interruptions, scheduled maintenance activity Summary:

President Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos has chosen Police General Francisco Marbil as the new head of the Philippine National Police (PNP). President Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos has picked Police General Francisco Marbil as the new head of the Philippine National Police (PNP).

item.title: Travelers return to Metro Manila, face heavy traffic after Holy Week
item.content:encoded:

Heavier traffic was reported on Monday morning as travelers returned to Metro Manila from the provinces following the Holy Week holiday weekend. The influx of people back to the city resulted in increased congestion on the roads, with many experiencing delays in their commute. The holiday weekend, combined with the return of individuals to work and school, contributed to the higher volume of vehicles on the streets. The traffic buildup was particularly noticeable during the morning rush hour as people made their way back to their regular routines after the extended break. Authorities advised commuters to plan their journeys accordingly and expect delays due to the heavier traffic flow. Despite the congestion, efforts were made to manage the situation and ensure the safety and efficiency of the roadways for all travelers. As the week progressed, traffic conditions were expected to normalize as the holiday period came to an end.

Summary:

Heavier traffic has been observed on Monday morning as travelers from the provinces returned to Metro Manila after a long holiday weekend during the Holy Week.

item.title: Syria says two civilians hurt in Israeli strikes on Damascus outskirts
item.content:encoded:
civilians, injured, Israeli strikes, Damascus, Syria Summary: Two civilians were injured in Israeli strikes on the outskirts of Damascus on Sunday, as reported by the Syrian defense ministry. This marks the second attack on Syria in a few days. The strikes targeted areas near the capital city, causing injuries to civilians and heightening tensions in the region. The Syrian defense ministry condemned the attacks, calling them a violation of international law and an escalation of aggression by Israel. The exact nature of the strikes and the extent of the damage caused are still being assessed. The incident underscores the ongoing conflict in Syria and the ongoing military actions taking place in the region. Efforts to de-escalate the situation and prevent further civilian casualties are crucial in addressing the conflict and ensuring the safety of the population. The international community will be closely monitoring the situation and working towards a peaceful resolution.

Summary:

Two civilians have been injured in Israeli strikes on the outskirts of Damascus on Sunday, the Syrian defense ministry said, in the second such attack on the country in a few days.

Summary: The Philippine Coast Guard is on high alert, and port operators are preparing for the influx of travelers expected after the long weekend during the Easter Triduum. The Coast Guard is maintaining a vigilant watch to prevent any maritime incidents, while port operators are making sure that all necessary arrangements are in place to accommodate the expected rush of passengers. With the holiday weekend coming to an end, authorities are focusing on managing the increased traffic at ports and ensuring that travelers reach their destinations smoothly. The Easter period is a busy time for travel in the Philippines, and both the Coast Guard and port operators are working together to handle the surge in passenger volumes and ensure a safe and secure journey for all.


The Philippine Coast Guard remained on high alert while port operators geared up on Sunday, in anticipation of the expected rush of travelers following the long weekend amid the Easter Triduum.

item.content:encoded:
Governor, Baltimore, bridge, federal funding, Democrats
Summary: Governor Wes Moore of Maryland called on Republicans and Democrats to work together to secure federal funding for rebuilding the collapsed bridge in Baltimore's harbor. The cleanup of steel debris is underway, and it is crucial to get the port economy back on track. The bridge collapse has caused significant damage, and immediate action is needed to address the situation. Governor Moore emphasized the importance of bipartisan cooperation to ensure that the necessary resources are allocated for the reconstruction efforts. It is essential for both parties to come together and prioritize the rebuilding of the bridge to support the local economy and ensure the safety of the residents.

item.title: Bulgaria and Romania join EU"s Schengen
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Sofia, Bucharest, airports, passport check points, Schengen Summary: Passport check points were removed at airports in Sofia and Bucharest on Sunday as Bulgaria and Romania partially joined the Schengen open-travel zone for most EU member states. Travelers departing to or arriving from these countries will no longer be subjected to passport checks. This move signifies a step towards easier and more convenient travel within the EU for citizens of Bulgaria and Romania. The removal of passport control points aims to promote seamless travel and enhance the integration of the two countries into the Schengen zone. This development is expected to boost tourism and facilitate business exchanges between Bulgaria, Romania, and other EU member states. The decision to partially join the Schengen zone reflects the ongoing efforts by Bulgaria and Romania to align with European standards and regulations, ultimately fostering stronger ties and cooperation within the EU. Summary:
Passport check points at airports in Sofia and Bucharest were removed on Sunday as Bulgaria and Romania partially joined the Schengen open-travel zone for most EU member states. This move allows for easier travel within the EU and promotes seamless integration. The initiative aims to boost tourism and facilitate business exchanges, aligning with European standards and regulations to strengthen ties and cooperation within the EU.

Airports in Sofia and Bucharest on Sunday removed passport check points for those departing to or arriving from most European Union member states as Bulgaria and Romania partially joined the Schengen open-travel zone.

item.title: Israel PM Netanyahu to undergo hernia surgery as Gaza war rages
item.content:encoded: Deputy Prime Minister and Justice Minister Yariv Levin will stand in while Netanyahu, 74, undergoes full anesthesia, his office said.

item.title: Pakistani man who filmed sister"s 'honor" killing arrested
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Pakistani, brother, sister, honor killing, arrested Summary: A Pakistani man has been arrested for allegedly filming his brother strangling their sister to death in the latest shocking "honor" killing in the country. The incident has sparked outrage in Pakistan, where such killings are unfortunately not uncommon. The man filmed the brutal act, which took place as a result of the sister dishonoring the family, and then shared the video online. This heinous act has once again brought the issue of honor killings to the forefront, shedding light on the deeply ingrained patriarchal norms and attitudes in Pakistani society. Authorities are working to bring justice to the victims of these senseless and tragic crimes, but there is still a long way to go in changing the cultural mindset that allows such acts to occur. The arrest of the man responsible for filming the murder is a small step towards justice, but much more needs to be done to put an end to these barbaric practices.

Summary: A Pakistani man has been arrested for allegedly filming his brother strangling their sister to death in the latest shocking "honor" killing in the country. The incident has sparked outrage in Pakistan, where such killings are unfortunately not uncommon. The man filmed the brutal act, which took place as a result of the sister dishonoring the family, and then shared the video online. This heinous act has once again brought the issue of honor killings to the forefront, shedding light on the deeply ingrained patriarchal norms and attitudes in Pakistani society. Authorities are working to bring justice to the victims of these senseless and tragic crimes, but there is still a long way to go in changing the cultural mindset that allows such acts to occur. The arrest of the man responsible for filming the murder is a small step towards justice, but much more needs to be done to put an end to these barbaric practices.

A Pakistani man who allegedly filmed his brother strangling their sister to death has been arrested as part of the latest "honor" killing that has outraged the country, police said Sunday.
